section.title: Your Xaraya installation
section.para: You have probably already downloaded a version of Xaraya and played around. If you haven't, well: let's give it a try!

Download the base distribution and do an install for a public site. Install all shipped modules and stick to the basic theme (Xaraya_Classic). This will give a nice overview of the possibilities of Xaraya.

section.title: Files and their locations
section.para: You can browse around in the Xaraya directory structure. You will first find some basic directories, but when you look further you can encounter several paths that you wouldn't normally see in a for instance static website.
The Xaraya core is placed in /includes, /var, /xaradodb, /themes and ...

The directory /modules hold all the extensions (modules). Make sure you have articles, categories, dynamicdata and example in there. There are more, but we will only mention these in this guide. The module example is the important example module that will serve as a template for our module later on.

section.title: Core API
section.para: Xaraya cannot live without the core. The core is there to do all basic operations in your installation. It provides services we need like the interaction with the database, generating the actual pages we see in a webbrowser, deal with security and many other basic tasks.

section.title: Modules
section.para: Modules are extensions that you can plug into the core. They act like little programs themselves. Modules can communicate with the core and with eachother via hooks.

section.title: Themes
section.para: Themes are the skins in Xaraya. A theme is a collection of templates and css files that uses blocklayout to generate the final pages users will see. You can add multiple themes to Xaraya, eg have your own theme and the print theme.

section.title: Hooks
section.para: Hooks are one of the nice key features of Xaraya. You will need some time to dive into the subject, but once mastered (and it's not that hard), you will see the enormous power.

Xaraya uses hooks to let parts of the installation talk to other parts. The Site Admin can decide which hooks to allow in which case. The hooks are called at the main actions in a module. Eg, when a new item is created, the new item hook is called. The module that calls the hooks doesn't need to know in advance what hooks it will call, but just does the call. The responding modules get information about the new item and can take their actions.

An example: When you have a module that will let the admin create new items (see the example module: admin-new), it is a good thing to call the new item hooks. This way, a module like dynamic data can show fields in the new item form that you don't need to program in there in advance. When the form is submitted to create the item, the function will call the create hook, which will send the data to the hooked modules. In the case of dynamic data, the create hook will store the data from the added fields together with information to which item the data is hooked.
